posts.cooked:
Hi, mentor from 5016 trying to help with their first swerve chassis.  Like most we don’t have a full set of 8 Falcons so I am looking to try and modify this example to use the Falcon’s for Rotation and Neo’s for drive. GitHub - BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Example: Yet Another General Swerve Library Example Project I would like to stay simple and use the encoders onboard the Falcon’s I know resolution is 1/2 what you get with a Cancoder, but we are really in the proving stage here.   Does anyone have anything I can look at on how to reference the internal encoder for this, or just tell me it isn’t possible.   Each swerve module has this config and none of the included encoder in the swervelib seem to map to the onboard one.

“encoder”: { “type”: “cancoder”, “id”: 1, “canbus”: null },

link_counts.title: GitHub - BroncBotz3481/YAGSL-Example: Yet Another General Swerve Library Example Project

posts.cooked: The reason you have the CANCoder isn’t for controlling purposes during the match, it’s to let your code know the physical rotation of your wheel when the robot turns on, as you can’t get that behind a gear ratio through the falcon encoder.  The swerve base cannot work right without it unless you want to manually align wheels to exactly the right position before each match.

Is it that hard to align and then zero at the start of a competition?  If we know the internal encoder is 2048 and our gearing is  then the code should know relatively close to what a full rotation would be?

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
You will have to align every single time you power cycle the robot. This is not impossible (paging @Andrew_L ) but you should definitely get some kind of absolute encoder on there if you can swing it. If you mess up even a single time, your robot will not drive correctly and you’ll be out for the match.

The Thrifty Bot has the cheapest analog option at $30. I work for Redux who has a CAN encoder for $45.

Which swerve module do you have?

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: I’ll have you know that we got our canandcoders on our modules now and take absolute readings so that we don’t have to ever worry about that again.
Thanks for the information, we have SDS mk4i’s.  Kids should be getting a Pigeon for IMU.  I will check out the encoders you have since $80 for a cancoder with wires is steep!

You can absolutely run with this configuration! You just need to modify the JSON files to support it, all of the resources I documented for it are in the discussion here . I haven’t updated the configurator in a while but the base should be very similar. The only real trick for falcons would be the to set the override for the angle encoder ticks per rotation to 2048 here .

Don’t feel constrained by the CANCoders either, you can use CANandCoders with YAGSL too.

Lastly I have seen a few teams use YAGSL successfully for a similar configuration (falcon drive, neo angle motor). I developed YAGSL with this exact scenario in mind too. Good luck!

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked:
We ran incrementals for steering 2012 and indexed start of match… but we also steered with windows motors so what the hell did we know.

We had a beam break on steering to index as well, but kept breaking them and just defaulted to start of match.
Thanks for the input y’all, I will work on implementing and let you know when we have success.  Thanks again.
